importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Hamas launched a coordinated attack into Israel, killing around 1,200 people and taking 251 hostages, marking a pivotal moment in the conflict and leading to a major escalation of hostilities.
Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh was assassinated in Tehran, significantly weakening Hamas leadership and disrupting its political structure.
Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar was killed in Rafah, eliminating another key military and political figure and further fragmenting Hamas command.
A ceasefire came into effect, triggering questions about whether Hamas would relinquish control of Gaza and hand over weapons, as per the US President Donald Trump’s 20-point peace plan.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from the 1980s to 2006 saw Hamas emerge as a political and militant force in Gaza, eventually winning control after a power struggle with Fatah and the PLO.

The period from 2023 to 2025 includes the outbreak of war on 7 October 2023, the deaths of major Hamas leaders, the destruction of tunnels, and ongoing debates over whether Hamas will relinquish control or reorganize under a new political identity.

keyTakeAways: Hamas has governed Gaza for nearly 20 years, using force to maintain control, and is now facing internal and external pressure to abandon its armed rule.
The group's extensive tunnel network — some extending 230ft deep and costing up to $6 billion — has been both a military and strategic asset, and is still being targeted by Israel.
Despite the deaths of top leaders like Ismail Haniyeh and Yahya Sinwar, Hamas continues to operate through splintered cells and a new generation of radicalized fighters.
The US President Donald Trump’s 20-point Gaza peace plan includes a transitional governance framework and calls for Hamas to hand over weapons and political control, but its feasibility is disputed.
Many Gazans, including aid workers and former Hamas advisers, believe Hamas may be willing to step back from power but remain skeptical due to its violent legacy and continued use of force.
Experts like Dr. Michael Milshtein and Ami Ayalon believe Hamas will remain influential in Gaza, with a new regime possibly emerging but still under Hamas’s shadow.

Iran and Qatar have historically supported Hamas, with Iran providing around $100 million annually and Qatar funding civil infrastructure, though some of this money may have been used for military purposes.
The humanitarian crisis in Gaza has intensified, with reports of looting, aid theft, and violence by Hamas forces against rival groups, raising concerns about law and order.
The future of Hamas is uncertain: it may rebrand as a political party, but its armed wing and ideology remain entrenched, suggesting continued conflict potential.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian militant and political group that has ruled Gaza for nearly two decades, known for its violent tactics, underground tunnels, and control of security in the region.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is the central subject of the article, with the focus on whether it will relinquish control of Gaza, disarm, or reorganize after two years of war and internal leadership losses.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President who proposed a 20-point Gaza peace plan including Hamas turning over weapons and submitting to an international stabilisation force.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s peace plan provides a framework for Hamas to step down from power, which the article assesses as unrealistic given current ground realities and Hamas’s resistance to disarmament.

namedEntities.name: Israel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The state that has been in conflict with Hamas since 2006 and has conducted military operations in Gaza, including targeting Hamas tunnels and leaders.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel is the primary military and political opponent of Hamas, with its military actions and strategic policies shaping the current situation in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: United Nations (UN)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international body that has accused criminal gangs in Gaza of stealing aid and reported on the humanitarian crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UN highlights the worsening humanitarian crisis and the breakdown of law and order in Gaza, which undermines the possibility of a peaceful transition of power.

namedEntities.name: Qatar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Gulf state that provided financial support to Hamas, including funds for civil servants and families, though some of it may have been diverted to military use.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Qatar’s support for Hamas is central to understanding the group’s ability to sustain operations in Gaza, especially during periods of conflict and economic strain.

namedEntities.name: Egypt
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A regional power that may contribute troops to a proposed international stabilisation force in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Egypt is one of the potential providers of a peacekeeping force under the Trump plan, suggesting a path to international intervention in Gaza’s governance.

namedEntities.name: Turkey
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A regional power that may contribute troops to a proposed international stabilisation force in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Turkey is another potential contributor to the international stabilisation force, indicating a multilateral approach to peace in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Iran
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A regional power that supports Hamas as part of its 'Axis of Resistance' against Israel and the US.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Iran is a key backer of Hamas, providing financial and military support, which underscores its enduring influence in the group's operations and survival.

namedEntities.name: Ismail Haniyeh
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former political leader of Hamas who was assassinated in Tehran in 2024.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His death marked a major blow to Hamas’s leadership and political continuity, raising questions about the future direction of the group.

namedEntities.name: Yahya Sinwar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Hamas military commander who succeeded Haniyeh and was killed in Rafah in 2024.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His assassination weakened Hamas’s military command structure and signaled the loss of key figures central to its operations.

namedEntities.name: Khaled Meshaal
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A senior Hamas political leader who survived an Israeli airstrike in Qatar in 2024 and remains part of the group’s political leadership.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His survival and continued presence suggest Hamas retains political influence despite violent attacks.

namedEntities.name: Ahmed Yousef
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A former adviser to Ismail Haniyeh and current Gaza-based think tank leader who believes Hamas may be tired of war and ready to transition to politics.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provides a critical perspective on Hamas's internal shift toward political governance and peace, suggesting a potential future transformation.

namedEntities.name: Michael Milshtein
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former head of Israeli Military Intelligence’s Palestinian Affairs department, who believes Hamas will remain dominant in Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He offers a skeptical view that any new regime in Gaza would still be under Hamas’s influence, emphasizing its enduring power.

namedEntities.name: Ami Ayalon
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former head of Israel's Shin Bet, who argues that defeating Hamas ideology requires a vision of a two-state solution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provides a long-term strategic perspective, advocating for a peaceful, two-state resolution as the only way to defeat Hamas’s ideology.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores the question of whether Hamas will relinquish control of Gaza after two years of war, during which it lost key leaders and faced severe internal and external pressure. While the Trump 20-point peace plan proposes a transitional governance structure and disarmament, the article questions its feasibility given the ongoing violence, Hamas’s use of brutal tactics against rivals, and the group’s deep-rooted military infrastructure. Despite the deaths of prominent leaders like Ismail Haniyeh and Yahya Sinwar, Hamas remains active through fragmented cells and new recruits. Experts debate whether Hamas will rebrand as a political entity or continue as a militant force, with some believing it may transition like the ANC in South Africa, while others predict continued conflict and dominance. The article highlights the role of regional actors—Qatar, Egypt, Turkey, and Iran—in supporting or pressuring Hamas, and underscores the humanitarian crisis, tunnel network, and ideological challenges that make any peaceful transition uncertain.
title: Will Hamas really relinquish control in Gaza?
